qas.question: Where in London are the Albert Memorial and Royal Albert Hall located?
What famous monument is located in Trafalgar Square?
The Monument, located in the City of London, was erected to commemorate what event?
What was the most common type of brick used to construct London's older buildings?

answers.text: yellow London stock brick or a warm orange-red variety

qas.question: Where are Marble Arch and Wellington Arch located?

answers.text: at the north and south ends of Park Lane

context: The Monument in the City of London provides views of the surrounding area while commemorating <a2_0>the Great Fire of London<a2_0/>, which originated nearby. Marble Arch and Wellington Arch, <a4_0>at the north and south ends of Park Lane<a4_0/> respectively, have royal connections, as do the Albert Memorial and Royal Albert Hall <a0_0>in Kensington<a0_0/>. <a1_0>Nelson's Column<a1_0/> is a nationally recognised monument in Trafalgar Square, one of the focal points of central London. Older buildings are mainly brick built, most commonly the <a3_0>yellow London stock brick or a warm orange-red variety<a3_0/>, often decorated with carvings and white plaster mouldings.
